--- Darren Izzard <zysyshelp@...> wrote:
> No, I took them all together. So up+left was
> diagonal; up+down meant no net
> vertical motion; etc.

Ah...gotcha.

Philip and I were talking about this as a possible
approach to a board-game algorithm...a neural net
agent that scans the board the way your nets scanned
the grid, then suggests a move. 

Was there any research along these lines that you read
beforehand?  Or has anyone else seen this approach to
board analysis/game play?

We were also thinking about the movement for such an
agent.  I like your representation, but we were
wondering how it might compare to giving such an agent
more mobility to move across the grid (instead of
moving a space at a time, perhaps the output could be
a vector, or coordinates for another section of the
board).  We also discussed the idea of letting such an
agent zoom in and out.  

Did you toy around with any of these ideas before
settling on your approach?  

> Generally, iirc, they went orthogonally straight for
> a bit until they hit
> the edge of a shape, diagonally across it until they
> hit an opposite edge,
> then orthogonally again to another edge, then made
> the decision. That seemed
> to be the general way they did it.

Hmm...and what was their success rate in guessing the
correct shape (I'm assuming they eventually evolved to
guess better than chance).

> Not other than here. I could send you the
> experiments.cpp file if you wanted
> to play with it a bit.

Sure...that'd be great.  There's actually a "Files"
section on the Yahoo Groups page.  I don't know if
there are restrictions on the sorts of file types they
allow you to upload, but it might be a nice idea to
try to upload it there first, in case anyone else is
interested in looking at it.  Assuming that you don't
mind distributing it.

Thanks,
Derek
